Pogi in pink: What impact will Pogaƒçar riding the Giro have on 2024 and beyond

Tadej Pogaƒçar has announced his racing programme for 2024, and in the first year when the 25-year-old can‚Äôt win the white jersey, he‚Äôs decided to have a punt at a whole new colour. For the first time in his career he‚Äôll take on the Giro d‚ÄôItalia, aiming to add the maglia rosa to his two maillots jaunes.

It‚Äôs a decision that has no doubt struck fear into the hearts of all his rivals. More importantly though, it gives him the chance to cement his place among the cycling greats. His 2024 programme will still include the Tour de France, meaning he could become the first cyclist since Marco Pantani in 1998 to win the Giro-Tour double in the same year.

It‚Äôs a feat that has only been achieved previously by other Hall of Famers: Eddy Merckx, Fausto Coppi, Bernard Hinault and Miguel Indurain all did it twice and Jacques Anquetil once. Several cycling commentators have compared Pogacar to Merckx for all his all-round ability, and Merckx himself has called him ‚Äòthe new Cannibal‚Äô ‚Äì so no pressure there, then.

Pogaƒçar‚Äôs decision to ride both Grand Tours next year won‚Äôt just have an impact on his own season and legacy: it could shape racing for all of next year and have a knock-on effect on his rivals. It also complicates his attempt to reclaim the Tour from Jonas Vingegaard ‚Äì so why is he doing it, and what does it mean?

Why this year?

At 25 he‚Äôs in prime physical shape and unburdened by injuries like last year‚Äôs fractured wrist at Li√®ge-Bastogne-Li√®ge ‚Äì which still wasn‚Äôt enough to prevent him from being a real Tour contender until late in the final week, so who knows what he could have achieved otherwise.

He‚Äôs also made it clear that the Giro has also been a goal. At the UAE training camp on Monday when his schedule was announced, he said, ‚ÄòI always wanted to do the Giro. It‚Äôs one of my favourite races because it‚Äôs close to Slovenia and as a kid we really loved to watch the Giro and go to the stages.‚Äô

It also fits with what we know of Pogaƒçar: a rider who races for the sheer love of it and seems physically incapable of turning down any challenge. He said, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm not so young anymore, and I think I can do two Grand Tours. I probably could have before, but it‚Äôs a nice time to have a new challenge in my career.‚Äô

Perhaps surprisingly, UAE Team Emirates didn‚Äôt discourage him in order to protect his Tour chances. Team boss Mauro Gianetti said, ‚ÄòEvery year we have a new project with Tadej. The past two years, it was the northern classics and the monuments. Now it‚Äôs time for the Giro.‚Äô

It makes sense that the team are planning to build up his palmar√®s across as many of cycling‚Äôs hallowed races as possible. Despite never contesting the Giro Pogaƒçar is entirely at home on Italian soil, with two wins at Tirreno-Adriatico, one at Strade Bianche, and a record-equalling hat-trick of consecutive wins at Il Lombardia.

And his own history is on his side. Famously, he was simply too good at the Vuelta a Espa√±a in 2019 to compete at the Giro the following year as planned, so UAE decided to take him straight to the Tour off the back of his third-place finish and best young rider victory in Spain. He won the Tour on his first appearance ‚Äì and you certainly wouldn‚Äôt be against him doing the same thing at the Giro.

What do the two routes look like?

Critics will ‚Äì and naturally, already have on Twitter ‚Äì argue that Pogaƒçar is hedging his bets by targeting the maglia rosa because Vingegaard has now bested him twice in a row in France.

And both races route profile would support such an interpretation. This year‚Äôs Giro features two time-trials, ideal for the Slovenian all-rounder to put time into his rivals, and avoids the high altitude in the Alps where he has suffered in the past.

Riders will face around 10,000 metres fewer of climbing than in 2023 and the race will be less backloaded than usual, making it a less brutal race overall and crucially less intense in its final week.

It‚Äôs also worth pointing out that the competition is less steep than at the Tour, with Ineos‚Äô Geraint Thomas potentially hoping to redeem himself after last year‚Äôs heartbreaking second-place finish, Wout van Aert possibly contesting GC for the first time at a Grand Tour, and Movistar‚Äôs Nairo Quintana back in the peloton after his suspension for a positive Tramadol test.

A 33-day break then follows ‚Äì two days more than normal ‚Äì for Pogacar to recover before attempting Grand Tour #2 of the year, which starts 29th June.

And it‚Äôs a blockbuster: pundits have pointed out that of the two riders, the 2024 Tour de France is better suited to Vingegaard, featuring numerous punishing summit finishes in a backloaded, heavily mountainous race. Most significantly, its final stage is a time-trial, a discipline in which Vingegaard dominated at last year‚Äôs edition, and which Pogacar would probably like to forget.

What does it mean for his competitors?

Speaking of Vingegaard: the ball is now firmly in his court. Visma-Lease a Bike (formerly Jumbo-Visma) have yet to reveal his schedule for 2024. Does Pogaƒçar‚Äôs announcement put pressure on his closest rival to broaden his own programme? Or will he stick to the Tour, where he and his team have dominated for the past couple of years?

The Danish rider is at his peak in the toughest, highest mountains in the Alps and Pyrenees, so it seems unlikely he would risk his chances of victory in France just to take on Pogaƒçar at the Giro. But across the rest of 2023, Pogaƒçar always had the edge over him in one-day racing and at Paris-Nice.

Theirs is a thrilling rivalry to watch and it would certainly be ideal for fans to see them go head-to-head for more than three weeks of the year ‚Äì but whether Vingegaard agrees is a different question.

The next question is, does Pogaƒçar‚Äôs decision to target the Giro narrow the field of potential victors at the Tour? He‚Äôs certainly a generational talent, but doing the double is a tough ask even for him. Do Primo≈æ Rogliƒç and Remco Evenepoel ‚Äì both nailed-on to race the Tour ‚Äì have a better shot at the maillot jaune if Pogaƒçar overstretches himself in the first GT of the year?

What does it mean for racing across 2024?

The downside is the possibility that racing could be less competitive. Pogaƒçar went into last year‚Äôs Tour having barely recovered from his wrist fracture, so it was always going to be an uphill struggle for him to take on Vingegaard. With three hard weeks of racing behind him, this year‚Äôs Tour could be a similar story ‚Äì although UAE and the man himself clearly don‚Äôt think so.

Racing at the Spring Classics will also be more open, with the Slovenian skipping most of them including his Tour of Flanders defence ‚Äì with the exception of Li√®ge-Bastogne-Li√®ge ‚Äì to fit in the Giro in May.

But there‚Äôs more to look forward to later in the season. Pogaƒçar will also target the Olympics road race and the World Championships, two titles he is yet to win. The latter in particular ‚Äì a hilly, punchy parcours in Zurich ‚Äì looks perfectly designed for his relentless attacking style.

And in many ways Pogaƒçar choosing to contest as much as possible in 2024, including two Grand Tours, can only be a good thing. He‚Äôs elevated the profile of the Giro even further and given himself the chance to tick even more boxes off the list of cycling‚Äôs most prestigious races.

When asked by interviewers whether he‚Äôd rather win the Giro or the Tour, he obviously said ‚ÄòBoth.‚Äô But he‚Äôs also said he‚Äôd rather win the World Championships for the first time than either of the Grand Tours.

It‚Äôs refreshing to see a top cyclist not just prioritising the Tour de France at the expense of everything else. He‚Äôs even said so explicitly: ‚ÄòI see myself skipping the Tour. Yes, it‚Äôs the biggest race in the world, but there are a lot of fun things to do in cycling.‚Äô

It‚Äôs an opinion that would have been unheard of a few years ago. Now it‚Äôs up to the rest of the peloton to make their move.

What does it mean for Pogaƒçar‚Äôs legacy?

Beyond demonstrating that there‚Äôs more to road racing than just three weeks in July, Pogaƒçar‚Äôs decision puts him in an elite bracket of riders to contest so many of cycling‚Äôs toughest races in one year. Only Eddy Merckx and Stephen Roche have ever won the triple crown: Giro, Tour, and world title in the same season.

None of cycling‚Äôs top athletes in recent years could do the double, not for want of trying: seven-time Grand Tour winner Chris Froome failed to win both in 2018, and Alberto Contador couldn‚Äôt manage it either. But if anyone can do it, let‚Äôs face it: it‚Äôs probably Pogi.

Pogaƒçar stands out as a natural, impulsive rider in a peloton that largely rides in a very controlled, machinist way. His joy for racing is infectious and fans can only hope that this decision to incorporate as many races as possible will mark a shift towards other riders being more experimental in their season planning.

That would get big names to face off earlier in the season than the Tour, and shift cycling‚Äôs centre of gravity away from what has always been its biggest race.

Regardless of whether he achieves the double, Pogaƒçar will go down in history as a rider who raced out of a genuine love for it. He encapsulates the spirit of cycling, racing as much as possible because he wants to win as much as possible.

In October he hadn‚Äôt finalised his schedule for 2024 and told Cyclingnews, ‚ÄòThe heart says to do everything, but you cannot do everything‚Äô ‚Äì and not for want of trying.

His brilliance at time-trialling, one-day racing, and longer stage racing makes him a threat in every race he enters, and his punchy style has understandably led to him being compared to the best of the best like Merckx and Hinault. Coincidentally of course, two riders who claimed the Giro-Tour double.

He may not be the most tactical rider in the peloton ‚Äì you could never accuse him of riding defensively or conservatively ‚Äì and that may not always pay off for him. But it certainly makes him one of the best to watch.

UAE Team Emirates manager Joxean Fern√°ndez Matxin said on Monday, ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs complicated to win two GTs but not impossible. And one of the riders for whom this is less complicated than for most is Tadej. I believe that with his character and his personality, he can do it. He is the special one. He is the best rider I‚Äôve come across in my career.‚Äô
